case_name: Registrar, High Court, Madras v. Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 993 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 993 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal arose by certificate from judgment and order dated March 31, 1967 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 1743 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated March 31, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 1743 of 1964.

facts.text: Madras High Court delivered judgment dated March 31, 1967 in Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd. v. The Registrar, High Court, Madras in Writ Petition No. 1743 of 1964 and Writ Petition No. 3891 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by certificate granted by the High Court, is directed against tin judgment dated March 31, 1967 of the High Court of Madras, in Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd. v. The Registrar, High Court, Madras   given in Writ Petition No. 1743 of 1964  and Writ Petition No. 3891 of 1965 .

facts.text: Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd. (petitioner) intended to file a suit in Madras High Court original side claiming relief valued at Rs. 2,06,552 against the Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Zenith Lamps and Electrical Limited, respondent before us and hereinafter referred to as the petitioner, intended to file a suit in the Madras High Court, on the original side, claiming a relief valued at Rs. 2,06,552, against the Revenue.

facts.text: Petitioner filed Writ Petition No. 1743 of 1964 questioning court-fee payable on the intended suit.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner filed Writ Petition No. 1743 of 1964 on the question of companyrt-fee payable on the intended suit, praying that the High Court may be pleased to issue a writ of mandamus or other direction order declaring Rule I of the High Court Fees Rules, 1956,

facts.text: Petitioner prayed for declaration that Rule I of High Court Fees Rules, 1956 and Madras Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act XIV of 1955 invalid insofar as relating to ad valorem scale fees.

anchor.surface_text: ...declaring Rule I of the High Court Fees Rules, 1956, and the provisions of the Madras Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act  Madras Act XIV of 1955  to be invalid and ultra vires insofar as they relate to the levy of fees on ad valorous scale.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that there was no justification for increase of court-fees in 1955 and 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended that Rule 1 of the High Court Fees Rules, 1956, was void and ultra vires because the Madras Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act  XIV of 1955  which had been applied in these Rules was void and ultra vires.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged from 1963-64 budget figures that fees levied exceed cost of administration of civil justice.

anchor.surface_text: From the figures of 1963-64 available from the budget for 1964-65, it is seen that the fees levied exceeds the companyt of administration of civil justice.

facts.text: State filed affidavit in reply on March 6, 1965 maintaining Rule 1 and Act valid, fees not excessive, gave figures showing expenditure on justice higher than fees in 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: This affidavit was filed on March 6, 1965. It appears that a supplemental companynter-affidavit on behalf of respondents 2 and 3 was filed on October 11, 1966.

facts.text: Supplemental counter-affidavit filed by respondents 2 and 3 on October 11, 1966 showing expenditure higher than receipts.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a supplemental companynter-affidavit on behalf of respondents 2 and 3 was filed on October 11, 1966. In this affidavit various statements were given to show that the expenditure on the administration of justice was higher than the receipts.

facts.text: Petitioner objected to filing of supplemental counter-affidavit after arguments started.

anchor.surface_text: The Petitioner took objection to the filing of the supplemental companynter-affidavit at that stage because it was filed after the arguments had started.

facts.text: Madras High Court struck down levy in Article I of Schedule 1 of Madras Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 in its application to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court struck down the levy found in Article I of Schedule 1 of the Madras High Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955, in its application to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court refrained from declaring entire Court Fees Act invalid as not contended.

anchor.surface_text: As it was number companytended before the High Court that the result of striking down article 1 of schedule 1 in its application to the High Court would necessitate the declaration of the invalidity of the entire Court Fees Act, it refrained from examining the position.

facts.text: State obtained certificate of fitness and filed appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State having obtained certificate of fitness filed the appeal which is number before us.

facts.text: Petitioner was not interested in pursuing the appeal and prayed no order for costs against it.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that the petitioner was number interested in pursuing the appeal and it prayed that if the appeal is decided against it numberorder may be made against it for companyts in the circumstances of the case.

facts.text: Supreme Court issued notice to Advocates-General and several States appeared.

anchor.surface_text: We issued numberice to the Advocates-Goneral and a number of States have appeared before us.

facts.text: State contended that expenditure on administration of justice higher than receipts per supplemental affidavit of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: He relied on the supplemental companynter affidavit filed on October 11, 1966. objection was taken on behalf of the res- pondent in the companynected civil appeals that this companynter- affidavit should number be taken into companysideration

facts.text: Supreme Court remanded the case to High Court for further consideration of affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly companystrained to allow the appeal and set aside the judgment passed by the High Court and remand the case to it.

issues.text: Whether Rule I of the High Court Fees Rules, 1956, and the provisions of the Madras Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act Madras Act XIV of 1955 are invalid and ultra vires insofar as they relate to the levy of fees on ad valorem scale in the High Court

anchor.surface_text: declaring Rule I of the High Court Fees Rules, 1956, and the provisions of the Madras Court Fees and Suits Valuation Act Madras Act XIV of 1955 to be invalid and ultra vires

issues.text: What is the nature of fees taken in court in entry 3 List II Schedule VIII of the Constitution? Are they taxes or fees or are they sui generis?
Is it necessary that there should be some relationship between fees taken in Court and the cost of administration of civil justice?
Whether the impugned impositions are fees

anchor.surface_text: The next question that arises is whether the impugned impositions are fees.

issues.text: Whether there is a broad relationship between the court fees collected and the cost of administration of civil justice such that the impugned levy is valid

anchor.surface_text: Various items both on the receipts side and the expenditure side have to be carefully analysed to see what items or portion of items should be credited or debited to the administration of civil justice.

arguments.claim: Fees taken in court logically come under Entries dealing with administration of justice; separate mention has no other significance; not taxes
Court fees are fees requiring quid pro quo/general relationship to cost of administration of civil justice, not general revenue
Legislature competent to levy varying fees based on relevant factors like value, steps in suit, upkeep costs, but not for general revenue (subject to Art 14)
Fees credited to Consolidated Fund (Art 266) not conclusive of being tax
State must establish no profit from civil justice admin; figures need analysis

anchor.surface_text: Various items both on the receipts side and the expenditure side have to be carefully analysed to see what items or portion of items should be credited or debited to the administration of civil justice.

arguments.claim: Whenever State increases fees generally, must show necessary to meet costs of civil justice admin
Court fees must contain essential elements of fees as per Shirur Mutt; if revenue for general purposes predominates, becomes tax

holdings.text: Fees taken in courts under Entry 3 List II are fees logically falling under administration of justice entries, not taxes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of legislative lists excludes court fees from general fee entries and distinguishes from tax entries; historical context supports as fees for services.

holdings.text: Fees taken in courts cannot be equated to taxes.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that fees taken in Court cannot be equated to Taxes. If this is so, is their any essential difference between fees taken in Court and other fees.?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax entries use word 'taxes'; court fees excluded from general fees showing distinction; no indication they are taxes.

holdings.text: Court fees require a quid pro quo in the form of a broad/general relationship between the levy and the cost of administration of civil justice, not arithmetical exactitude.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Shirur Mutt and Mica case; fees distinguished from taxes by correlative services; applies to civil justice administration.

holdings.text: Legislature is competent to levy varying court fees taking into account relevant factors like value of dispute, steps in suit, upkeep costs, subject to Art. 14, but not for general public revenue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fees must relate to civil justice costs; cannot tax litigation for other purposes like roads or education.

holdings.text: Court fees are not a separate category (sui generis) but must contain essential elements of fees as per precedents like Shirur Mutt; if revenue for general purposes predominates, it becomes a tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with HC; applies Shirur Mutt test; scrutinize if levy relates to services or is excessive as tax.

holdings.text: Whenever State Legislature generally increases court fees, it must establish necessity to meet costs of civil justice administration; cessation of broad relationship makes it a tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionality requires justification for increases; beyond competence if for general revenue.

holdings.text: Fact that fees credited to Consolidated Fund under Art. 266 is not conclusive of them being taxes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from Shirur Mutt; all revenues go there regardless.

holdings.text: State must prove no profit from civil justice by analyzing receipts and expenditures attributable to it.

anchor.surface_text: Various items both on the receipts side and the expenditure side have to be carefully analysed to see what items or portion of items should be credited or debited to the administration of civil justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on state for enhancement; requires affidavits and scrutiny; leads to remand.

precedents.citation: The Indian Mica and Micanite Industries Ltd. v. The State of Bihar and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Mica and Micanite Industries Ltd. v. The State of Bihar and others 1 by Hegde, J. and the observed From the above discussion, it is clear that before any levy can be upheld as a fee, it must be shown that the levy has reasonable

precedents.case_name: Indian Mica and Micanite Industries Ltd v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: levy upheld as fee requires reasonable relationship with services rendered by Government as quid pro quo, general not exact arithmetical
precedents.cited_holding: From the above discussion, it is clear that before any levy can be upheld as a fee, it must be shown that the levy has reasonable relationship with the services rendered by the Government. In other words the levy must be proved to be a quid pro quo for the services rendered.

anchor.surface_text: A.T.R. 1971 S.C. 1182 at p. 1186. We may not dispose of other arguments addressed to us. We are not able to interpret the phrase fees taken in court to mean that it described fees which were actually being taken before the Constitution came into force.

precedents.case_name: Indian Mica and Micanite Industries Ltd v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: fees must relate to administration of civil justice, legislature cannot tax litigation for general revenue

precedents.citation: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1 , it was held A tax is a compulsory exaction of money by public authority for public purposes enforceable by law and is not payment for services rendered.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner Hindu Religious Endowments Madras v Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: crediting revenue to Consolidated Fund not conclusive of it being a tax; definition of tax vs fee as payment for special service
precedents.cited_holding: A tax is a compulsory exaction of money by public authority for public purposes enforceable by law and is not payment for services rendered. [...] The distinction between a tax and a fee lies primarily in the fact that a tax is levied as part of a common burden, while a fee is a payment for special benefit or privilege.
